document.masterDocTitle: A taxonomic review of the genus Asterostegus (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea), with the description of a new species

bibRefCitation.author: McKnight D. G.
bibRefCitation.refString: McKnight D. G. 2003. A new species of Asterostegus (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea) from the Cook Islands, South Pacific Ocean. Species Diversity 8: 385 - 389.

figureCitation.captionText: Fig. 6. Asterostegus maini McKnight, 2003 (NIWA 7564, H-733). A. Aboral view. B. Oral view. C. Aboral periphery of disc. D. Aboral central disc. E. Jaws. F. Oral periphery of disc. G. Lateral disc. H. Aboral proximal portion of arm. I. Aboral middle portion of arm. J. Oral proximal portion of arm. K. Lateral middle portion of arm. Arrows indicate positions where oral interradial plates should exist (F, G). Abbreviations: ADS = adoral shield, AS = arm spine, GS = genital slit, LAP = lateral arm plate, Te = teeth, Ten = tentacle, Tu = tubercle.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Astroceras elegans McKnight, 1989: 25
(non
Astroceras elegans Bell, 1917
).
Asterostegus maini – Okanshi & Fujita 2013: 568, 571, 575, fig. 1, tables 2-3 .

subSubSection.paragraph: About 10 tubercles present on periphery of radial shields, ca. 250–300 µm long. On proximal portion of arm, three to five tubercles on top of each lateral bar. Three to five oral interradial plates forming one row.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype ( NIWA 7564 , H-733), ethanol preserved specimen, vicinity of Pukapuka Atoll , Manihiki Plateau , Cook Islands , New Zealand , 10˚53.0’S, 165˚55.2’W – 10˚52.4’S, 165˚55.4’W,
417-446 m depth
,
21 Apr. 1986
.

subSubSection.paragraph: MEASUREMENTS. NIWA 7564, H-733: disc diameter 22 mm , arm length at least 205 mm (arms convoluted).

COLOUR. McKnight (2003) described the colour of the holotype as “In ethanol, areas between radial shields as well as dorsal surfaces of arms light brown, rest of body creamy-white”. However, by our observation, the holotype is uniformly creamy white. The colour might be diluted in long term ethanol preservation. Colour in life is unknown.
Only known from off Cook island, 417-446 m depth, New Zealand ( type locality, McKnight 2003 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 6.
Asterostegus maini McKnight, 2003
(NIWA 7564, H-733). A . Aboral view. B . Oral view. C . Aboral periphery of disc. D . Aboral central disc. E . Jaws. F . Oral periphery of disc. G . Lateral disc. H . Aboral proximal portion of arm. I . Aboral middle portion of arm. J . Oral proximal portion of arm. K . Lateral middle portion of arm. Arrows indicate positions where oral interradial plates should exist (F, G). Abbreviations: ADS = adoral shield, AS = arm spine, GS = genital slit, LAP = lateral arm plate, Te = teeth, Ten = tentacle, Tu = tubercle.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Asterostegus maini
is related to
A. tuberculatus
in sharing relatively small tubercles and multiple oral interradial plates on each interradius, while
A. sabineae
possess relatively large tubercles and only one oral interradial plate.

Asterostegus maini
and
A. tuberculatus
can be distinguished by the size and arrangement of tubercles on the disc, the number of tubercles on lateral bars, and the number and arrangement of oral interradial plates ( Table 1 , see also remarks for
A. sabineae
).
